Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Computing Cluster for Multidisciplinary Research and Education at the University of Northern Colorado

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Northern Colorado (UNC) requests $139,948 over 36 months for the acquisition of an HPC Cluster for Multidisciplinary Research and Education. Research projects include biology, computer science, mathematics, and atmospheric sciences.
The proposed UNC HPC cluster is available to all of UNC, including training courses for new users. It is expected that some courses (specifically bioscience and computer science) will utilize the cluster. Outreach activities include the UNC 'Frontiers of Science Institute' which is a summer program for Colorado high school students in STEM disciplines. The PIs plan on implementing a program with the UNC Math and Science Teachers Institute to train K-12 teacher in advanced topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this MRI project has been to acquire a High Performance Computing (HPC) cluster for the University of Northern Colorado in order to support its research and education programs in a number of disciplines including biology, mathematics, computer science, exercise science and earth and atmospheric sciences.

Enabled by this grant, the University of Northern Colorado now owns and operates a 300-core in-house HPC cluster with:

  • Two mirrored Lenovo head nodes, each including two Intel Xeon 6-core 2.4GHz processors, 96GB of DDR4 memory, 240GB of SSD and 96TB of HDD storage (RAID 5), and 2 10Gb/s Ethernet adapters,
  • 15 identical compute nodes, each including two Intel Xeon 10-core 2.3GHz processors, 192GB of DDR4 memory, 120GB of SSD storage, and two 10Gb/s Ethernet adapters,
  • 10Gb/s Ethernet supported by a 10GBe switch connected to the UNC network infrastructure by a Gigabit Ethernet switch,
  • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system for HPC with the ROCKS suite for scheduling and management, Intel and GCC compiler suites, and a variety of other (mostly open-source) discipline-specific compilers and software tools.

The HPC cluster has enabled UNCO to expand and strengthen its faculty’s individual and collaborative research programs. Examples of such programs are:

  • Energy Efficiency in Wired Computer Networks: Computationally-intensive simulation models of Energy Efficient Ethernet (EEE) at 40 Gb/s and higher have been developed on the cluster and used for modeling Dual-Mode EEE and studying its tradeoffs. The power consumption and the added packet delay for Dual-Mode EEE were measured by the simulation models on the cluster and the results were matched with analytical models for the same performance parameters. Another set of simulation experiments were performed on the HPC cluster that addressed the tradeoffs of an addition to Dual-Mode EEE called Packet Coalescing.
  • Functional genomics of childhood leukemia: In a collaborative project with researchers at the University of California San Francisco, the cluster has been used to perform genomic and transcriptomic analysis of precursor B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia samples. The data generated from this project has helped secure NIH funding and to begin to characterize the genetic networks that contribute to this disease.
  • Characterization of non-model organisms: Utilizing massively parallel DNA-sequencing data, the cluster has been used to generate and characterize de novo DNA sequence assemblies from several different venomous snakes and fruit bats.
  • Atmospheric Modeling: A new configuration of the Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (RAMS) has been set up on the cluster and is currently being used as a weather forecast model with a high-resolution inner nested grid that encompasses Colorado.

To date, the results of research enabled directly or indirectly by the cluster have been published in more than five scientific manuscripts.

The cluster has also enabled training courses for undergraduates and graduate students. The HPC cluster has provided opportunities to expose the students to new education and research experiences using an advanced and effective resource. An example is the development and offering of CS 460/560: Problem Solving with Supercomputers; This course covers lectures with discussions and hands-on activities that provide students with an opportunity to gain proficiency in basic use of supercomputers. Additionally, students participate in predefined team-based exploratory projects which enables students to actively explore solving real-world problems using the HPC cluster environment.

In summary, the HPC cluster continues to be a large-scale modern computational resource which enhances the progress of research projects across a spectrum of investigations at UNC. It has also increased the scientific computing literacy in UNC graduates by providing more students with meaningful quantitative research experiences.
